components.name: opening_quote
components.text: You miss 100% of the shots you don't take  -  Wayne Gretzky

components.name: intro_message
components.content:
Greetings! ! !  After much effort, my personal website is finally online.

Whether you came here through a link, entered in the URL yourself, or maybe stumbled onto my website accidentally, feel free to take a look around. All the contents on this website can be accessed through the navigation menu on the left.
Here, you can find out {more} about me, {what I can do}, and {what my interests are}. You can also take a detailed look at some of my past {projects}. If you'd like to see some sample code in action, here are some {web games} that I wrote in Javascript and I strongly encourage you to try them. In addition, I will also be maintaining a personal tech {blog} in which I will offer some fun discussions on various technical subjects.
If you like the design of my website and want to find out how it is done, you can read about it {here} or check out the source code from this Github {repository}.

components.name: new_content
components.content:
1. My first {blog post}, "A Cautionary Tale on the Dangers of Deploying AI in Social Media", has been added.
2. My custom {article} {editor}, which I used to create much of my website content, has been updated to support highlighted code blocks. For example the html file for this page can be seen below:
<>
3. My website and its corresponding editor, have been updated to support a subsection of the {Markdown} standards. 
For example: **bold**, *italic*, ~~strikethrough~~, ~underline~, [word]^superscript^, and [word]^^subscript^^ can all be added to my website articles via the article editor. These new features will allow me put emphasis, add citations, or issue corrections on my website.

components.name: new
components.content:
1. A new blog post is in progress. It will be a fun exposition on the emergence of strong AI in the not so distant future.
2. A Websocket implementation of my {GoVariantClient} project is planned. It is expected to be significantly less complex that the original C++ equivalent.
